main event: On 3 March 1956 in Columbus, Ohio, there was a ground-visual observation of two round objects, two inches in diameter, sometimes colored from white to amber, and identified as balloons. The observation lasted for 5 minutes and was concluded to be probably balloons due to the presence of thunderstorms in the area and beacon lights nearby.
interesting points: The observation lasted for 5 minutes, allowing for a thorough examination of the objects.
The objects were described as round and two inches in diameter, sometimes colored from white to amber.
The conclusion that the objects were probably balloons was based on the presence of thunderstorms in the area and beacon lights nearby.
No photographs were included in the report to visually document the sighting.
There were several aircraft in the area at the time of the observation.
sighted object: two round objects, two inches in diameter, sometimes colored from white to amber
witnesses: a student and a GOC member
